comments.body:
Can we not export this publicly? Just call it _NoValue or something? We
have enough public clutter as it is, and this adds zero value.
On Mar 14, 2015 9:15 PM, "Charles Harris" notifications@github.com wrote:

In numpy/**init**.py
https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/5683#discussion_r26444409:

> @@ -132,6 +132,15 @@ class VisibleDeprecationWarning(UserWarning):
>      pass
> 
> +class NoValue:
> -    """Special keyword value.
>   +
> -    This class may be used as the default value assigned to a
> -    deprecated keyword in order to check if it has been given a user
> -    defined value.
> -    """
> -    pass
>   +

Two blank lines ;)

â€”
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/5683/files#r26444409.
Hmm, I guess it doesn't need to be public, so `_NoValue` would work.

comments.body: This looks like a mistake to me - removed in #14881
Tweaked these messages again. Kept with `np.compat.{}` just to be safe, as it's the only change guaranteed not to break user code.

Yeah, I saw. I like the tweaks, thanks.  For me I am happy to put this in, was just planning to wait a day or two in case of feedback.
Thanks for the info @WarrenWeckesser.

comments.body: `unicode` is also defined in `np.compat`. We may want to deal with that at some point. It is unfortunate that it is part of the default numpy api.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +159,163 @@    # TODO[gh-6103]: Deprecate these
    from builtins import bool, int, float, complex, object, str
    unicode = str

    from .core import round, abs, max, min

comments.body: No need for the try/except, right? Accelerate generates a warning, not an error.
There is a value error post the rank warning, hence catching the ValueError, we can also add the error message. The Value Error is a shape mismatch error, due to the failed dgelsd initialization.
